title: The White Page
description:
Rain threads like silver needles through the silk screens of the Veilhouse of Whispers, and every murmur sounds like a confession practicing how to be forgiven. In a lamplit chamber the masked child of the Ledger tips a scale, and the pan with a single white page lowers as if it were breathing, as if a mercy had lungs and was afraid. Sorev Dusk stands among swaying debt-threads that quiver like kelp in a turning tide, his amber tools laid out like scalpels meant for ghosts. He admits what the Veilhouse would rather swallow than speak: the Ledger’s most dangerous mercy, a white page from the secret book of pardons, has been stolen by a hand that thought kindness is simple. The thief has hidden it in the Hollowwind Barrows, where the fluted vents sing when the river rises and the Hollow Choir rehearses the year’s disasters in harmonies no living throat can carry.

The city’s knives have been sheathed by ledgers for too long to remember their first quarrels, and that is both salvation and peril. If the thief reads the page in a wrong chamber, names will wash away that should not, and the debts that keep feuds predictable will dissolve into an unpriced storm. Aren Siltwarden, Reedbound by birth and burdened with a river-oath spoken before Mereth Tydel, is asked to walk the singing mounds and recover the mercy without letting the Ledger own the deed. To do this will mean listening to the dead until his skin prickles with all the futures they fear, finding the bone-quiet niche where the page lies like a sleeping dove, and confronting a living motive that is not wicked, only reckless. The river takes payment in secrets and in kings; tonight it asks for judgment carried on calloused hands.
objectives: Travel to the Hollowwind Barrows at low wind and locate the vent whose song has soured.
Decode the Hollow Choir’s warnings to determine which tragedy can be averted this flood-cycle.
Find the hidden ossuary niche where the white page is kept and retrieve it without tearing or speaking it aloud.
Confront the thief and resolve the motive behind the theft, then return the page to Sorev Dusk with conditions.

dialogue.speaker: Sorev Dusk
dialogue.lines: We traffic in endings, Aren, but even we respect a proper punctuation, because a sentence cut too short becomes a scream and a sentence that never ends becomes a lie. The white page can end a debt the way rain ends dust, and it can also wash a street clean of names that should remain to anchor the living in their rightful grief. Someone took it to be kind, believing mercy is a blade without an edge, and kindness wielded without craft can be the cruellest blade we ever sharpen. Bring it back without letting it speak, and I will pay with more than coin; I will pay with silence exactly where you most need it, along a thread that has been tugged by too many curious fingers. Return it with conditions that keep it from becoming an indiscriminate flood, and I will stitch those conditions into our masks so that anyone who breathes through them inhales your boundary as law.

dialogue.speaker: Yerin Pale
dialogue.lines: The Ledger is a necessary fever that breaks worse fevers, or so we tell ourselves when our hands ink names into dark books that never sleep. A pardon page is not forgiveness; it is a valve, and when opened without witness it can drain a neighborhood of what little justice it holds in common. Retrieve the page, and I will see that it is not used to erase a truth the city needs, because some truths are ballast that keep our hull from flipping. I know you burned a debt once, and I also know the warmth of that fire still smolders in you; consider this a chance to temper the heat rather than quench it. Give me a page returned with a condition wrought in public breath, and I will bind that condition with three seals so any violation costs the violator his night and his name.

dialogue.speaker: Mereth Tydel
dialogue.lines: Mercy is a tide, Aren, and tides must be kept by bells and moons or they drown the very altars that bless them. The Hollow Choir does not sing to frighten us; they sing because warning is the only alms the dead can give the living without dimming. If you must claim this page, do so with your mouth closed and your heart loud, for a single spoken syllable near such a page can wake a covenant older than our records. Return it to the hand that asked, but let that hand be steadied by a witness that is not bought, so that the city knows mercy arrived in daylight even if it was carried by night. Should you need it, I will stand within ringing distance and speak a patient amen that cools tempers the way shade cools wet stone.

dialogue.speaker: Sila Jor
dialogue.lines: Listen to the vents the way a scribe listens to a memory well: count the intervals where the air stumbles, and you will hear the place that has forgotten its own song. The Hollow Choir’s warnings come in triads, and the third note is always the hinge that shows you what cannot be changed and what can be turned, like a lock that yields to the correct pressure. Walk widdershins around any mound whose grass grows against the wind, and if your shadow doubles itself, you are near an ossuary used for arguments rather than sleep. Do not answer the wights if they ask your name, because they will try to make you pay the moon-toll in secrets that are not theirs to keep. If your skin rises all at once as if a cold hand brushed every hair, step back and breathe the clarity sap, then continue with a steady pace as though you planned to be brave all along.

dialogue.speaker: Hollow Choir
dialogue.lines: We sang a flood once and no one listened until the boats grew teeth, so now we sing in thirds and let the wind carry the part that hurts least. A dock-street will drown in knives over a debt that was born crooked, a hospice bell will fail to ring for an hour that matters, and a child will learn to breathe water and never forgive the city that made it necessary. Of these, the bell can be righted if a page remains silent, and the knives can be sheathed if a single oath is written with a joint hand in sight of bones. We cannot stop the child, for tides crown their own, but we can spare the hour that decides how many beds will be empty by dusk. Do not read the page where bones are angry; carry it as if it were a sleeping bird and let it wake where breath is honest and counted.

dialogue.speaker: Sava Deren
dialogue.lines: I took the page because the Ferrymen are being hunted by a feud that fed itself on a lie, and one more body on the dock would teach nothing but how to stack grief higher. The Ledger would arbitrate in whispers and let the truth be neat; I need the truth to be loud enough that even the river hears it and changes its eddies around it. I hid the page where the dead could watch me decide, because I wanted witnesses who do not owe me favors and cannot be bought with stall-leases. My first-born’s name drifted off the Moonbridge years ago, and I will not lose two dozen more sons and daughters to a quarrel that should have been dissolved when that dockmaster’s murderer confessed in a drunkards’ prayer. Take it back if you must, Aren, but do not give it back raw; make them swallow a condition so strong that even their masks taste of iron and rain.

dialogue.speaker: Aren Siltwarden
dialogue.lines: I have ferried anger until its hands learned to unclench, and I have watched coins decide who got to live long enough to be sorry, so do not mistake my patience for softness. I will walk the Barrows with my mouth closed and my ears open, and if the dead sing me a warning I will carry it like a pole across my shoulders until it makes the work easier. If I lift your page, I lift it as if it were a sleeping bird; I will not startle it into flying where it can cut anyone with the wind from its wings. I will bring it back, Sorev, but it will wear a collar woven from witness and vow so it cannot run where it bloodies a kindness. Let that be our bargain: I return what is yours to keep, and you bind it so that even you cannot use it without first tasting the river’s memory of this night.

choices.title: Bind the page with a Temple witness, then return it to Sorev.
choices.text: You invite High Acolyte Mereth Tydel to the edge of the Barrows and ask her to stand within bell-ring while you recover the page, not to seize it, but to watch your hands. You speak no syllables of the page, but you ask Mereth to lay a simple, public vow upon it that it may not be read unless a bell is rung thrice before a crowd who knows what is at stake. You then carry the silent paper back through rain-streaked alleys to the Veilhouse, each step a statement that mercy must be seen even when it is quiet. Sorev meets you beneath the debt-threads, and you insist the Temple’s witness be written into the Ledger’s record beside the pardon’s shelf-number. The room feels colder when the maskwright agrees, because the Veilhouse is not accustomed to sharing breath with sanctuaries, but you hold your ground until the ink dries.
choices.outcome: The Night Ledger accepts the return under protest that tastes like courtesy, but its acceptance is real and recorded in three places where even erasures leave scars. Mereth’s vow becomes a bell hidden inside the page, and any future attempt to read it without ringing will sour like a flood gone septic, forcing the Ledger to seek daylight before it can pour mercy. Yerin Pale gives you a nod that is almost a bow, acknowledging that you protected the city’s need for both mercy and memory. Sorev pays in coin and in a silent favor, arranging for a thread of questions about you to simply stop tugging at your life for a season. On the river, word travels that the Ferrymen’s brewing knife-night has been delayed by a single, stubborn oath, and the Brass Menders ring their bell-tree once just to tell you they noticed.

choices.title: Broker a three-hand oath between Ledger, Menders, and Ferrymen that limits the page’s single use.
choices.text: At the foot of a singing mound you bring Sava Deren, a Brass Menders delegate, and Sorev Dusk into the same wind and force them to endure the Hollow Choir’s prophecy together. You lay the white page on a slab that once taught kings humility, and you dictate a condition: one use only, read by Sorev while Sava and a Mender count the bell-strokes aloud and a Ferryman’s pole lies across the page like a crossbar. You require the chosen use to be the prevention of the dock-street knife-night the Choir named, and you say it must be read before witnesses with the names of the spared recorded in the Archives. No one smiles while they agree, because compromise tastes like medicine, but all three know the alternative is blood that would not distinguish between guilty and hungry. You wrap the page, reclaim it, and walk it back to the Veilhouse with the three-hand oath braided around it like river-grass.
choices.outcome: The Ledger enters the tri-seal with ill grace and true ink, and a single line of script on the page grows warmer when it is brought near the named dock-street as if the page recognizes its duty. The knife-night is averted two evenings later when a reading in public forces a crooked debt-keeper to choke on his own arithmetic, and crews that came to cut find their hands busy witnessing instead. Sava Deren swears a season of restraint at the weirs, gaining you a grudging smile from Quill Vess’s people who prefer calculus to knives. The Brass Menders credit you when the hospice bell rings on time that week, and they quietly reserve a bed for anyone dragged bleeding from politics. Your name becomes a password among marsh pilots meaning stand firm but leave the channel open, and the Ledger’s respect for you rises even as its masks learn the new taste of being supervised.

choices.title: Hide the page in the Concordant Archives for one breath to inscribe restraint into its memory, then return it with that constraint.
choices.text: You carry the page to the Concordant Archives under a cloak that does not entirely hide the weight your hands feel, and you ask Sila Jor to lower a memory-wire into a shallow well. With care bordering on prayer, you hold the page over the still water long enough that the well tastes its blankness and remembers a rule: it cannot be read unless a river-oath is spoken by you or your named successor. You do not let it touch the water, and you do not speak, but you feel the moment the restraint takes, like a knot tightening in wet rope. You lift it away, wrap it again, and make for the Veilhouse before the wind can change and blow gossip through the Archives’ shelves. When Sorev receives it, you state the constraint plainly and offer your oath to be present when mercy is poured, so that the city’s memory sits in the room even if the city is not invited.
choices.outcome: Yerin Pale senses what was done and chooses, after a long pause, not to be angry because the result is a tempering rather than a theft, and because some safeguards are as old as the city itself. The Veilhouse writes your river-oath into a margin that is not supposed to admit names like yours, and a quiet ripple moves through the Ledger’s knives as they realize this mercy now has a chaperone. The Archives owe you nothing and say so, but when you next pass their doors the water in the nearest well calms in approval like a cat blinking. The page is safe and reserved, its single breath of restraint held like a stone in a sling until it is needed, and you have kept your promise not to let anyone weaponize kindness. Menders whisper that perhaps ledgers can be taught manners, and for a short while the city’s rumors sing that you taught a page to listen before it speaks.

choices.title: Return the page directly to Sorev in secret, but demand a white-book act and a binding not to read without you.
choices.text: You choose the narrowest stair in the Veilhouse and a room whose walls remember long agreements, and you place the wrapped page on a table carved with permanent ledgers. You ask for no audience but Sorev’s and the masked child’s scale, and you demand two things: a white-book pardon to wipe a predatory ledger that has been choking the Saffron Bank, and a binding vow that the page will not be read unless you place your hand on the bell-rope that signals witness. You make it clear that if either term is refused, you will walk the page into the Tide-Temple at noon and let the bells write the rest, and the threat hangs in the air like river-light before a storm. Sorev understands leverage when he tastes it, and you can see the mathematics of mercy being done in his eyes even as his pride arranges itself into a mask. When the nod comes, it is slight but total, and you hear the masked child’s scale sigh as a white slip of old paper is taken from the ledger and burned to cancel a skein of quiet strangulations.
choices.outcome: The white-book act travels through Prism Market faster than the smell of star-fruit, and several families stop drowning on dry land that same week without knowing which hand threw them a rope. The binding vow is stitched into the Veilhouse’s rules with a needle of silence, and no one can find the seam unless they are invited to pull it, which they will not be. Night Ledger reputation climbs for you because you returned a blade without nicking its edge, and Brass Menders’ approval warms because you used that return to stop a cruelty that wore a calculator’s smile. The page sleeps on its shelf with a string knotted to your name, and for once a thing of power is not lonely because it is not allowed to act without company. Your passage through Veilhouse wards becomes easier, the air parting with the politeness reserved for guests who have proven themselves more useful than dangerous.

rewards.description: 20 silver coins minted at the Ledgerhall of Tithes, stamped with three ratifying seals
Veilhouse Mask-Token: one-time safe audience with the Night Ledger without being unmasked
Whisper-Grass Wreath: advantage on reading omens and barrow songs while worn
Night Ledger reputation +2 and Brass Menders reputation +1 for returning a mercy without letting it be abused
Quiet passage through Veilhouse wards for you and one companion once per moon-turn
